content.question:
A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.

You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

Mary and Chance walk in the same direction along a straight path. For <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 20"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, Mary’s velocity at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="M of t, equals, the fraction with numerator 6010, and denominator t squared, minus 3 t, plus 50.5, end fraction"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>6010</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>50.5</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> and Chance’s velocity at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="C of t, equals, 8.5 times t cubed, times e raised to the negative 0.45 t power"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>8.5</mn><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.45</mn></mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Both <math alttext="M of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are positive for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 20"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and are measured in meters per minute, and <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in minutes. Mary is 12 meters ahead of Chance at time <math alttext="t equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and Mary remains ahead of Chance for <math alttext="0 less than t, less than or equal to 20"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a)   Find the value of <math alttext="one tenth times, the integral from, 5 to 15, of, M of t, d t"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mfrac><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>15</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>M</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. Using correct units, interpret the meaning of <math alttext="one tenth times, the integral from, 5 to 15, of, M of t, d t"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mfrac><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>15</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>M</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.

frqParts.text:
A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.

You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

Mary and Chance walk in the same direction along a straight path. For <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 20"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, Mary’s velocity at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="M of t, equals, the fraction with numerator 6010, and denominator t squared, minus 3 t, plus 50.5, end fraction"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>6010</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>50.5</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> and Chance’s velocity at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="C of t, equals, 8.5 times t cubed, times e raised to the negative 0.45 t power"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>8.5</mn><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.45</mn></mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Both <math alttext="M of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are positive for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 20"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and are measured in meters per minute, and <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in minutes. Mary is 12 meters ahead of Chance at time <math alttext="t equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and Mary remains ahead of Chance for <math alttext="0 less than t, less than or equal to 20"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a)   Find the value of <math alttext="one tenth times, the integral from, 5 to 15, of, M of t, d t"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mfrac><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>15</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>M</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. Using correct units, interpret the meaning of <math alttext="one tenth times, the integral from, 5 to 15, of, M of t, d t"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mfrac><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>15</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>M</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.
(b)   At time <math alttext="t equals 10"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, is Mary speeding up or slowing down? Give a reason for your answer.

(c)   Is the distance between Mary and Chance at time <math alttext="t equals 18"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>18</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> increasing or decreasing? Give a reason for your answer.

(d)   What is the maximum distance between Mary and Chance over the time interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 20"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

topic.text: 4.2: Straight-Line Motion - Connecting Position, Velocity, and Acceleration

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
